title: What are third places, and are they disappearing or just changing?
text:
Chances are you've been to a third place at least once in your life and didn't even realise.

Essentially public lounge rooms, they are social environments separate from home (first place) and work (second place).

And while many believe they're essential, some experts say they're becoming a lot more scarce. So what are they, and are they going anywhere? ﻿

A third place could be anywhere from a coffee shop to a park. (Sydney Morning Herald)

The term "third place" was coined in the 1990s by ﻿sociologist Ray Oldenburg as work hours began to increase.﻿

He argued that as life became busier and more secluded, these places became vital for democracy, engagement and a sense of place amongst the broader community.﻿

The main criteria for a spot to be a third place are pretty simple: it needs to be a neutral area that is easily accessible to and comfortable for the public.

Its main purpose is for people to gather and socialise, fostering a sense of community and conversation. ﻿

READ MORE: Three words this CEO swears will help you land a better job ﻿

The main purpose of third spaces are to foster a sense of community with strangers. (Getty)

In a traditional sense, a third space can be anywhere from a coffee shop to a park to a library.

"Shopping centres are considered third spaces," creative producer at youth arts organisation OutLoud Nicole Issa said.

"Even though some people might not like it to be, it's the truth."

She says third places are important for social connections, particularly amongst young adults.

She also thinks they're dying out.﻿

"One thing that I'm hearing a lot from young people is that there is a need for third spaces and there's a need for safe places for young people to go," she said.

﻿"I think it's been a gradual thing. The biggest, major event that has changed the way young people use third space was definitely COVID...

Many believe that shopping centres are also considered third place. (JOE ARMAO)

"There was like strict legislation that came in that prevented people from going to social events or even meeting up with other people, which then, in turn, just changed people's patterns."

However, unlike Issa, University of Melbourne Chair of Architecture and Urban Design Kim Dovey does not believe that third spaces are dying, but rather that they never existed in Australia to begin with.

﻿"The concept of the third place is an American thing," he said.

"It sort of came out of that kind of social capital literature.

"These places are important because they're where we establish what are often known as weak ties.

"You make new friends and acquaintances, and you get to know your neighbourhood and your neighbours a bit more and people you wouldn't normally run into.

"In so many parts of the world, it's just normal everyday life. It didn't really need a name."

The emergence of social media has allowed for the growth of digital third places. (Getty)

In his literature, Ray Oldenburg argued that a place outside of work and home is crucial for public wellbeing.

"What suburbia cries for are the means for people to gather easily, inexpensively, regularly, and pleasurably - a 'place on the corner'," he said.

While brick-and-mortar shopping centres filled that need for decades, the rise of online shopping has meant people are spending less time at physical stores.

The internet – particularly social media – is a double-edged sword here. While it's given rise to digital third places, it's limited the way that people interact in public.

"I hate having to get out of the way of people who are reading their phone as they walk down the street, they're not actually present in the street," Professor Kim Dovey said.

"Cities work by putting lots of people you don't know into the same space that you share, and you weave in and out of each other and on busy pedestrian sidewalks."

"And that's how cities work, so I think social media is a threat to that."

title: Bumpy road ahead for Australia's bicycle industry
text:
Christmas couldn't come fast enough for the Australian bicycle industry, which has been buffeted by a post-pandemic slump.

Bike sales ballooned during the COVID-19 health emergency , with cycling one of the activities permitted during lockdowns.

Research by industry analysts IBISWorld shows bikes were then flying off the racks as Australians embraced the activity, spurring a jump in profits from 2020 to 2022.

Cycling remains popular in Australia, but the bike industry has recorded a slump in sales since the end of the pandemic. (Lydia Lynch)

Stock levels across Australia were soon strained and as the virus led to lockdowns and factory shutdowns in the key manufacturing hubs of China and Taiwan , they became exhausted.﻿

But then the brakes came on as the global economy kickstarted post-pandemic, with cost-of-living pressures making new bicycle purchases a low priority for households.

One bright spot has been continuing high demand for parts, accessories and repair services.

Bicycle Industries Australia chief executive Peter Bourke said retailers, manufacturers and importers were counting on ﻿the festive season this year.

"Christmas and the summer months have traditionally been our strongest periods ... the wrapped bicycle under the Christmas tree is still a popular present," he said.

Demand for bicycles in Australia and other countries boomed during the pandemic but then quickly fell off. (AP)

Traditional bike shops continue to hold advantages over online retailers, including expert fittings, personalised advice and a skilled repair service, but they face a shifting market. ﻿

One example, highlighted by the IBISWorld research released in 2025, was Pedal Group's 99 Bikes chain of stores across Australia.

The company expanded rapidly, increasing its number of physical stores to boost its market share.

But since the close of the pandemic, slumping demand caused the company to deal with oversupply issues, hampering its expansion.

And Australian cycle companies are not alone in facing a post-COVID sales slump.

Remember Peloton? ﻿The sports company turned out millions of exercise bikes and treadmills fitted with smart technology, fuelled by demand from fitness enthusiasts who were confined to home.

Sales of Peloton fitness bikes boomed during the pandemic, but then fell off after lockdowns lifted. (Supplied)

Sales boomed during lockdowns, but Peloton's fortunes began to fade as vaccinations increased, gyms reopened and rivals offered competitive products.

Once the darling of the US stock market during COVID, by February 2022, its share price had collapsed and a painful company restructure followed, including shedding 2800 workers.

The rising popularity of e-bikes is also another challenge to sales of conventional, or analogue, bicycles.

﻿The technology is expanding the market by appealing to a wider range of consumers than conventional, or analogue, bikes, requiring less pedalling and easier hill-climbing.

Many bike shops are now stocking e-bikes, but they've been competing with sales from private individuals and online suppliers, often spruiking powerful and illegally altered machines.

E-bikes have provided both a threat and opportunity for conventional bike sales. (Jorens Seins/iStock)

Australian import regulations controls on e-bikes were relaxed in 2021, leading to a flood of such e-bikes capable of travelling at more than 50km/h.

But in December 2025, after a spate of deaths and serious injuries of e-bike riders, federal and state authorities agreed to reinstate a key import standard to define legal e-bikes.

This would include the motor cutting out at a maximum assisted speed of 25km/h. ﻿

Looking ahead, the hope is a safer and better-regulated market will create a level playing field for established bike dealers.

Bourke says the industry is adapting to the heady changes, but the traditional local bicycle store selling everything, from children's bikes with trainer wheels, to mountain bikes, commuter machines and racing cycles is probably on its way out.

title: US company buys Queensland's Hamilton Island
text:
Hamilton Island is set to change hands as its owners offload the tropical paradise to a private equity company in the US.

Blackstone has acquired the famous Queensland resort owned by the billionaire Oatley family for more than two decades.

The deal, which could see the US company become a major force in Australia 's hospitality sector, is now subject to regulatory approval.﻿

READ MORE: Enormous bull shark caught off Queensland coast

Hamilton Island is set to change hands. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Blackstone has more than $1.2 trillion in assets globally and took over Crown Resorts for $8.9 billion several years ago.

The Oatley family ﻿acquired the popular tourist destination in 2003 after it won a bid for 100 per cent of the shares in Hamilton Island when it was a publicly-listed company.

The late Bob Oatley, a renowned Australian winemaker and patriarch of the family, wanted to establish Hamilton Island as a destination anyone on any income could enjoy.

US private equity company Blackstone has acquired the famous Queensland resort. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

The Oatley family has spent more than $350 million on improvements to the island, which has won more than 50 awards in recent years.

Blackstone chairman of Asia Pacific and head of Asia real estate Chris Heady told the Australian Financial Review the company wanted to build on the Oatley's investment in the island.

"Hospitality and leisure is a key investment theme at Blackstone globally including in the Asia Pacific region, where we've brought scale and operational expertise to invest in and build leading brands," Heady said.

"We are committed to investing in the long-term success of Hamilton Island, its people, and its local businesses and community."

title: Faye's great Christmas cake baking mission
text:
Hordes of people flock to car parks to meet Faye Taylor, who waits ready to hand out one of 500 of her handmade Christmas cakes.

A wide variety of different people slip in and out of their vehicles excited to see Faye, who stands beside a car boot overfilled with eskies and bags.

They contain cakes which have lovingly been hand wrapped with personalised notes attached.

Hundreds of cakes are delivered across Faye's Riverland community. (ABC Riverland: Shannon Pearce)

Many share brief but animated conversations with Faye, who lives in South Australia's Riverland region.

One who has turned up to collect a parcel is Tanya McDonald, who doubled her order this year.

"They just taste bloody lovely," she said.

" This lady is a real treasure; there's not many around like her anymore. "

While the time and ingredients are donated by Faye, the funds raised by selling the cakes help children in need overseas.

All funds raised from the sale of cakes will continue to go to helping children overseas. (ABC Riverland: Shannon Pearce)

It is this need that drives her to carry out the monumental baking task, which started in September.

Not just a cake

Faye said she fitted baking around her day job and, although it was difficult at times, the cakes helped her out of some trying times.

Every cake is carefully wrapped in festive colours, ready to be opened by families in the region and further afield. (ABC Riverland: Shannon Pearce)

"At my lowest of lows this year, I thought, 'No, I'm not going do it'. [But then I thought], 'Yes, I'm going push on,' " she said.

"It helps you get out of that mental fog because those people that I saw [overseas], have got nothing, literally nothing.

"But they're so happy, they're happier than the people here."

Baking for hope

Faye said her calling to bake was inspired by a missionary trip to Africa 28 years ago.

"I came back from Africa wanting to sell my house, because I just had so much and I felt embarrassed how much I had, after seeing what little they have," she said.

" I definitely think of them all the time. My heart, my heart is with them all the time. "

Faye's memories of her Missionary trip to Africa have stayed with her. (Supplied: Faye Taylor)

Funds raised from selling the cakes go to Hope Village Orphanage in Indonesia as well as a ministry at Naivasha in Kenya.

Faye said she visited the children at the Hope Village Orphanage in 2024 and was able to see where her donations go.

She said funds were directed to support children's needs, including meals, clothing, medical support, housing expenses and education.

Faye was proud to see first-hand where her donations have been used while on a trip in 2024. (Supplied: Faye Taylor )

The helping hands

Glenda Cass is just one of the many people who buy Faye's cakes.

She started buying at Christmas several years ago and it wasn't long before she offered to lend a hand.

"I've developed her ingredient labels according to SA Health regulations and I print them off every year for her as a donation," she said.

From baking to wrapping, Faye has remained committed to the cake effort for almost 20 years. (ABC Riverland: Shannon Pearce)

Glenda said her devotion to continuing to support Faye was driven by knowing the money was going to people who needed it and because it sparked memories of her grandmother's traditional Christmas cakes.

She said it was what Christmas was all about for people of faith.

Faye's talents and passion for baking also includes making festive biscuits. (Supplied: Faye Taylor)

"It's part of her faith, it's part of what she believes," Glenda said.

"Her and her husband would give anybody in the community the shirt off their back to help them out and not question it.

" That to me is what a true Christian is about, but it's also what a community person is about. "

Ministry of cake

As the cakes are enjoyed at dinner tables in the Riverland and further afield today, Faye said she was pleased her job was done for another year.

With the cakes out for another year, Faye can take a break from the kitchen. (Supplied: Faye Taylor )

But she said it would not be long before she was pulling the apron back on.

"When God tells me to stop, I'll stop, but right now I'm open to keep going," she said.

"Every year by the time they are all cleared out, I think, 'Oh, now I've got my fridges back, now I've got my eskies back', but then it's sort of, 'Oh, it's time to start again.'"

title: Pope Leo criticises 'distorted economy' in first Christmas mass
text:
Pope Leo XIV has led the first Christmas mass of his pontificate, greeting thousands of faithful in unusually informal style in St Peter's Square before the Christmas Eve service.

During the mass, Leo said Christmas was a feast of "faith, charity and hope" and criticised a "distorted economy" that "leads us to treat human beings as mere merchandise".

The pontiff, who has made care for immigrants and the poor key themes of his early papacy, said Jesus's birth showed God's presence in every person as he led the world's 1.4 billion Catholics into Christmas.

"On Earth there is no room for God if there is no room for the human person. To refuse one is to refuse the other," Leo said during the solemn service.

Earlier, he spoke in front of St Peter's Basilica to offer Christmas wishes and thank those who had come to follow the mass on outdoor screens, despite rainy weather.

"St Peter's is very large but unfortunately it is not large enough to receive all of you," he told the crowd of about 5,000.

The US-born pope has adopted a more discreet and moderate style to that of his charismatic predecessor Francis, who died on April 21.

The mass was attended by high-ranking Church figures, diplomats and about 6,000 faithful.

Pope Leo XIV's first Midnight Mass in St Peter's Basilica. (AP: Gregorio Borgia)

Leo stuck to a very religious homily without any direct reference to current affairs.

The ceremony celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ and is one of the most important days in the Catholic Church calendar.

The service combines traditional music with symbolic gestures such as placing a statue of the baby Jesus in a cradle.

The 70-year-old pope decided to hold the mass at a later time than under the more elderly Francis, who would hold Christmas mass at around 7:30pm local time.

In another change, Leo will hold another mass on Christmas Day on Thursday, renewing a tradition started by the late pope John Paul II.

Pope Leo XIV will return to the basilica for Mass on Christmas Day followed by his traditional blessing from the loggia. (Reuters: Guglielmo Mangiapane)

He will then give his "Urbi et Orbi" blessing at midday local time from the balcony of the basilica — during which popes usually speak about conflicts around the world and call for peace.

Leo on Tuesday called for a global truce around the world on Christmas Day, expressing "great sadness" that "apparently Russia rejected a request" for one in Ukraine.

"I am renewing my request to all people of good will to respect a day of peace — at least on the feast of the birth of our saviour," Leo told reporters at his residence in Castel Gandolfo near Rome.

Christmas 2025 also marks the end of the Catholic Church's Jubilee Holy Year, which has brought millions of pilgrims to Rome.

Cardinal Pierbattista Pizzaballa arrives at the Church of the Nativity, in the West Bank city of Bethlehem, on Christmas Eve. (AP: Ariel Schalit)

Meanwhile, thousands of people flocked to Bethlehem's Manger Square after two years of subdued celebrations because of the war in Gaza.

Christmas festivities return to Bethlehem after two years For the first time in two years, Bethlehem has restarted its Christmas festivities to "reignite the spirit that everybody needs" while Palestinians continue to live under restrictions.

Bethlehem, where Christians believe Jesus was born, had cancelled Christmas celebrations during the war.

But on Wednesday, local time, a giant Christmas tree was back in Manger Square, temporarily replacing the wartime nativity scene of baby Jesus surrounded by rubble and barbed wire in a homage to Gaza's suffering.

Cardinal Pierbattista Pizzaballa, the top Catholic leader in the Holy Land, kicked off this year's celebrations during the traditional procession from Jerusalem to Bethlehem, calling for "a Christmas full of light".

Cardinal Pizzaballa said he came bearing greetings from Gaza's tiny Christian community, where he held a pre-Christmas Mass on Sunday.

AFP/AP

title: In sport, music and even maths, finding 'the zone' is a beautiful thing
text:
There is a state of mind athletes talk about when they are totally absorbed in the moment and the actions of their sport.

They call it being in "the zone", a "flow state" or simply "flow".

In his seminal 1972 book on sports psychology, The Inner Game of Tennis, author W Timothy Gallwey championed quietening the analytical, critical inner voice to allow one's unconscious mind to take over.

He described how a non-judgemental approach to the game can lead to being in the zone.

"There is a feeling some call harmony, balance, poise, even peace, or contentment," Gallwey wrote.

In his book, Sacred Hoops, legendary Chicago Bulls basketball coach Phil Jackson espoused a similar philosophy.

"All of us have flashes of oneness," Jackson wrote.

"When we're completely immersed in the moment, inseparable from what we're doing."

Being in the zone or in flow is that intangible state of total absorption where things just happen often without conscious thought — when what was difficult seemingly becomes easy.

You see it in sport when a tennis player nails every shot, when a cricketer is seeing the ball like a balloon, when a footballer kicking at goal just can't miss or when a runner seemingly floats.

An athlete in that "flow state" is a sight to behold. (Getty Images: Shi Tang)

In that moment everything falls into place and performance levels often go to a new plane.

But it's not only sport — flow states can be experienced by anyone undertaking any task.

You may have experienced flow at work, meditating, or even going for a run.

Sportspeople covet flow, but it's an amorphous state — temporary and often fleeting — a gift bestowed by the gods that can arrive and then disappear like a wisp of smoke.

Flow means different things to different people, let alone how they arrive in flow state or stay there.

Here we find out what flow means to an international cricket captain, a record-breaking marathon runner, an ARIA award-nominated musician, a prize-winning mathematician, and a performance psychologist.

What does flow state feel like?

The cricketer

Heather Knight is one of the most decorated women to have played for the England cricket team.

She captained the side to the 2017 World Cup victory and was the first woman to score an international century in all three formats of the game.

Both Heather Knight's Test centuries came in the Ashes against Australia. (Getty Images: Harry Engels)

"I think it's something that you don't get into too often — that sort of that state where everything just feels like it's clicking," Knight said.

"It's just real clarity in your thinking and clarity in decision-making.

"You're not thinking too much but you're thinking a little bit; you're thinking the right things.

"For me, as a batter, like your decision-making is really sharp. You almost feel like you know what the bowler's going to bowl and you just feel quite invincible, really.

"You execute the skill exactly how you want to: You middle the ball, hit it where you want to and it just feels quite easy and effortless and quite light."

The musician

Tim Levinson is better known by his stage name, Urthboy.

He's a founding member of the hip hop group, The Herd, and an acclaimed solo performer, with seven albums to his name.

He ran a record label, Elefant Traks, and produced and managed other musicians.

"Flow state's just deep work," Urthboy said.

"It really is just getting into a place where you have clarity, you have focus, you have a sense of some kind of coherent goal even if it's not a tangible thing.

"It's just you're moving and intellectually something about the wiring and the connecting of ideas and themes.

"There's a sort of fluidity between the steps along the way, so, there's less blockage; there's no second guessing; there's less stopping to think."

The runner

Jessica Stenson broke the Australian women's marathon record in Valencia in December.

During the race she described being in a flow state.

Stenson won a Commonwealth Games gold medal and two bronze medals and competed in two Olympic Games.

"It [flow] has a bit of an air of effortlessness about it," Stenson said.

"So, you're obviously doing something that consumes a lot of energy and it's a difficult task, but at the time it just feels like it's coming really naturally.

"I think it's a state where your mind is very absorbed in the moment, and you obviously feel sensations, but you're not really hanging on to them or judging them.

"You're just experiencing the feelings and feeling at peace."

Finding a cadence is hugely important for any long-distance event. (AP: Isaac Parkin/PA)

The mathematician

Professor Geordie Williamson is the director of the Sydney Mathematical Research Institute.

He's won international mathematical prizes and in 2018 became the youngest living Fellow of the Royal Society.

"You enter this beautiful state that's very fleeting, very difficult to attain, where you don't have a sense of time," Williamson said.

"You feel a complete kind of freedom within the problem, and it's often at those moments that really beautiful things can happen.

"Calculations are really hard for a while and then at some point you get such an ease with them that it just all fits together.

"It feels right and you know you're going in the right direction.

"Often I've found what I would kind of identify as flow states not whilst working with a pen and paper — like whilst walking around — and you feel this like very beautiful freedom in your mind, like all the pieces can just assemble as they should.

"It's completely addictive."

The performance psychologist

Caroline Anderson has worked for two decades as a performance psychologist.

Most recently she was the lead psychologist with the Australian Olympic team in Paris.

"I would describe flow as just that real task absorption and process focus where we're not thinking about consequences," Anderson said.

"There's less self-referential processing or thinking going on in the brain.

"We stop thinking about the pressure. The pressure is there, it's just that we're not choosing to focus on it, cause we're directing our focus towards other things."

How often do you experience flow?

Heather Knight

Knight scored 157 against Australia in the 2013 Ashes in one of the finest knocks of her career and looks at the innings as a prime example.

"Maybe a session I think where I really got into that flow," Knight said.

"Once or twice a season potentially across the whole year. So, that's a lot of cricket games that probably you're not in that state.

"I was able to think really clearly, move really freely. It's just when your body moves exactly how you want it to, you play the shots, you time the ball, you hit the ball where you want to."

Urthboy

Urthboy says flow is about clarity and focus. (Facebook: Urthboy)

Urthboy feels flow most powerfully on stage.

"When you're performing — maybe there's a forgiveness for making mistakes of course — but you don't want to be getting into a spot where you're thinking at all," Urthboy said.

"In the studio you can be slow moving to that zone or you can be clarified in your thinking.

"It took me a long time to understand that you're a vehicle to some extent with the way that ideas flow through.

"It's not really that you have all this control and you have all the answers. It's more that there are things that are floating in the air and you're capturing them and you're able to weave them into your process.

"You're working with it as opposed to having control of it."

Jessica Stenson

Stenson finished 12th in the Paris Olympic Games marathon. (Getty Images: Christian Petersen)

Stenson hit a flow state during her 2022 Commonwealth Games gold medal run but it can still elude at key moments.

She didn't find it much at the Paris Olympics, despite still being happy with her performance, and can feel it powerfully away from athletics.

"Maybe two or three times a year. I would say, you know, maybe in a race maybe there are the odd training sessions, but it's a pretty rare feeling," Stenson said.

"[In Valencia] I didn't feel exhaustion, it was a pace or an effort I'd practised so often in training, and it felt like I was moving really efficiently, so, it almost felt like I was like floating across the ground.

"I would say I feel flow state more when I'm doing art than I do when I'm running.

"I love painting and drawing and I've always thought when I'm painting and drawing time just flies and I just don't want to stop."

Geordie Williamson

Williamson has found the flow state of mind in the past but has revealed it can be more difficult as time goes by.

"It takes a lot of time to get there. Often I'll spend many weeks or months grappling with a problem and then slowly you start to know its moving parts," Williamson said.

"I would say that in the past it was quite a regular feature in my life.

"I have small children, and small children definitely reduce the amount of time you spend in flow state — I can testify to that."

Can you bring on flow deliberately or does it just happen naturally?

Heather Knight has led England against all-time great Australian teams. (AAP: Dave Hunt)

Heather Knight

"There's like little routines that I have to try and get me in the right mind state that I know I need to have to perform," Knight said.

"Like I'll scrape my guard three times and tap my foot before I take the ball, particularly early in in my innings, cause it sort of resets me after the last ball — it sort of prepares me.

"I might play a shot that I have to commit to — so, playing a reverse sweep actually helps me get into that zone."

Urthboy

"There are all these different ways of which you open up the door and go through it," Urthboy said.

"A lot of it is time, giving time to something. In the studio definitely.

"On the stage, you don't have time — you've just got to be there.

"In the studio you can be slow moving to that zone or you can be clarified in your thinking.

"If you give time and availability to the idea, you have always a different pathway to how quickly you can get to that spot."

Jessica Stenson

"I think it's more of a 'ooh I'm here now,'" Stenson said.

Stenson has won a Commonwealth Games gold medal and two bronzes. (Getty Images: Cameron Spencer)

"But I did try to be intentional [during the Valencia marathon], which I haven't done much in marathons before — to try and switch off my thinking a little.

"There's a blue line that you follow in a lot of marathons, and I remember just looking down at the blue line and listening to my feet and trying to remove any other thoughts and that I feel kind of prompted that state a little."

Geordie Williamson

"You absolutely cannot bring it on deliberately," Williamson said.

"You can really want it badly and it doesn't happen, and then sometimes it'll happen out of nowhere, like, 'oh, great'.

"It's very, very unpredictable, I would say.

"You can try to encourage it, I think not being busy is critical.

"And also, like a really, really focused engagement with the problem. That very deliberate practise I think is a prerequisite.

"I also feel that kind of meditative aspects can also be helpful. Like paying attention to the wind on your face and that kind of thing can help bring it on."

How important is flow?

All athletes search for that "zone", but it's hard to find. (Getty Images: Matt King)

Heather Knight

"I think certainly I've learned throughout my career that you don't have to be perfect to perform," Knight said.

"It's actually when you're not feeling like that and you you're able to put in performances and score runs, that's when you're at your most valuable.

"Certainly, it's something to strive to, and all the athletes are certainly searching for it, but yeah, it doesn't happen very often.

"But I think If you search for that perfection — that flow — all the time and expect to reach it all the time, you're setting yourself unrealistic targets."

Jess Stenson

"I think you don't want to go into a race expecting that you'll feel it, because then you open yourself up to feel disappointed or stressed that you're not there," Stenson said.

"I go into a race expecting it's going to feel really hard and so if it comes, it's very welcome.

"I think it's fun to acknowledge it while you're in it, but I know that there are so many ups and downs in a marathon and while you can be feeling brilliant one moment, you might not feel great the next."

Sometimes everything just clicks into place. (Getty Images: Nicolas Economou/NurPhoto)

Caroline Anderson

"I really like the concept of flow. I think it's great to talk about as an interesting piece, I just don't think it's the be all and end all," Anderson said.

"For the majority of sports, it's not something that we want to have as a goal — it's something that can either happen or doesn't, and that's great either way.

"I believe there's a paradox where the more we want to be in flow and the more expectation that we have that we have to be in flow in order to perform well, probably the less likely we are to get in flow.

"And I think we can get a trap if we think that the only way to get high performance or a gold medal result is through flow."

Some final words from performance psychologist, Caroline Anderson, on how she helps athletes create a mindset that could lead to flow state.

"I think one of the barriers that people have is normal nervousness, performance anxiety, anticipatory anxiety, pressure, whatever you want to call it leading into an event," Anderson said.

"When you have a good understanding of what your body's doing and why it's doing it — and this is a normal phenomenon — we can kind of stop battling it and we just work with what we have.

"I think learning how to be more present-moment focused in your training [is important].

"We're just not very good at this in our modern lives, right?

"And athletes describe this all the time — they're doing something, but their mind is somewhere else.

"So, the present moment focus, and then being really clear about task or process related cues.

"A basketballer knows how to shoot a basket without thinking about it. When they're at the club or when they're training, they can do it completely automatically.

"In a high pressure moment that automation doesn't exist, because our mind wants to go to the threat, it wants to go to the crowds, the consequence — what if I lose?

"We need to give our minds really clear process, technical related cues, even if it sounds simple.

"So, what's my body stance? What arm position do I want to have? What do I want to do with the release of the ball? It sounds simple, but we need to give our mind these anchor points because otherwise it's just going to go in different directions.

"And the more that we train those, the more likelihood we are to go into flow."

title: Long public transport trips are now a go-to for holiday homecomings
text:
It is an 11-hour journey by train and bus from Melbourne to Broken Hill, but for Scarlet Kohane, whose family moved to the regional town a couple of years ago, it is the only affordable option.

"As a young person with a casual job, the thought of spending over $800 on a round-trip flight ... I just couldn't justify it," she said.

Her one-way trip cost $64 — comprising an $11 train ticket from Melbourne to Mildura via Swan Hill, and a $53 ticket from Mildura to Broken Hill.

Scarlet Kohane is taking the 11-hour public transport journey from Melbourne to Broken Hill to see her family this Christmas. (ABC Shepparton: Ethan Seiderman)

Ms Kohane said the five-hour trip to Swan Hill on a packed train, followed by six hours on buses through Mildura to Broken Hill, was worth it.

"Saving [for the airfare] would take time and if I were to drive, petrol is costly too," she said.

But the journey is not without its challenges.

"It can get pretty cramped on the V/Line this time of year," Ms Kohane said.

"I used to catch the train to Castlemaine for family Christmas and sometimes I had to sit on the floor."

Not meeting holiday demand

Ms Kohane’s journey is becoming increasingly common, as rising airfares and fuel costs push more Victorians onto regional rail.

But while demand for V/Line services has surged, capacity has largely remained unchanged, leaving passengers to deal with packed carriages and fully booked services.

Victorian Nationals MP Annabelle Cleeland said the Albury line was strained on a normal weekday and demand exceeded supply during holiday periods.

"Even one extra return service on the busiest days would make a real difference," Ms Cleeland said.

She said trains offered a safer, affordable option for older people and those with a disability, and not everyone could, or should have to, drive.

"Improving rail is about providing a reliable alternative, not forcing people onto it," Ms Cleeland said.

Euroa MP Annabelle Cleeland is pushing for increases to services on the Albury line to meet demand. (Supplied: Annabelle Cleeland)

A Victorian government spokesperson said extra services were added to the Albury V/Line bus and train network last year.

"We've given Albury Line passengers more options to get where they need to go, with two weekend train services and more coach options added to the timetable," the spokesperson said.

"And with free weekend travel this summer, we continue to encourage passengers to plan ahead and make a reservation before travelling," the spokesperson said.

Public transport will be free today and on New Year’s Eve and extra services will be available to help regional travellers get to the Boxing Day Test cricket at the MCG.

Daniel Bowen says Victorian commuters are welcoming an increased investment in public transport. (ABC News: Costa Haritos)

A busy year for V/Line

A record 26 million passengers boarded V/Line services last financial year, up from 24 million the year before.

Public Transport Users Association spokesperson Daniel Bowen said it made sense to keep investing in the system.

"Normally in Victoria the maximum fare you'll pay is $11 a day and that's not bad value for travelling long distances," he said.

He said more services were needed to reduce a high strain on the system especially on north-east Victorian services.

Public transport will free for children in Victoria from New Year's Day. (Ethan Seiderman)

Victoria will offer free public transport for children under the age of 18 from the beginning of 2026.

Paul Strickland, La Trobe University senior lecturer in sport, tourism, hospitality and events, said the fare incentives would help the hospitality industry and the environment.

But he warned such decisions were also conditioning children not to pay for public transport.

"If you're a seven-year-old and you're taking public transport, you're doing that for free for [over a decade] and then all of a sudden you have to pay, there's going to be an issue," Dr Strickland said.

"I don't know any model around the world where public transport is absolutely free."

Transport Victoria announced last week it would increase the fare cap to $11.40 for both metropolitan and regional trains from January 1.

title: 'We push it to the max': She ready to add to Sydney to Hobart history
text:
Philip Bell and Mark O'Dea have very different sailing origin stories, but they work very well on the water — and this year they are coming together again to race She in the Sydney to Hobart yacht race.

They and the rest of the crew will honour the boat that has more experience in the 628 nautical mile (1,163km) blue ocean classic than all but a handful of craft in the race's long history.

They will also mark a man that connects them both, a former owner and skipper of She who died a year ago.

She is a modified Olsen 40 boat — indeed it has been more modified than most, thanks to that former owner, the late Peter Rodgers.

Bell is the current skipper and the man who bought the boat from Rodgers more than a decade ago.

A semi-retired civil engineer who ran his own business for many years, he acknowledges he didn't have the usual start to his sailing career.

"Most people take it up [early], they say it was at five years old or something," Bell says.

"I was 60 years old. I did a Yachtmasters course then.

"I reckoned you need to be rich or have lots of time on your hands [to do this].

"I started looking around for a boat and that's a pretty daunting task. Eventually I found a boat and [She] had actually done 17 Sydney to Hobarts and I said, 'Oh, that must be a fairly robust boat.'"

First stop Hobart, next up Osaka for Annette and Sophie For Annette Hesselmans and her daughter Sophie Snijders aboard Fika, the Sydney to Hobart's 628 nautical mile bluewater classic is just a qualifier for the Melbourne to Osaka marine marathon.

Bell says he never intended initially to do offshore racing. But then he sailed a couple of times with O'Dea, who had been second-in-command on She under Rodgers.

"As I started doing a little bit of racing just here locally and I realised that the ship, she had become a bit of a men's shed," he said.

"We've got a lot of people over 60 sailing, a lot of men over 60 [and] of the 10 people who are regulars with me, I would say six of them have been with me for 10 years.

"So it became sort of a little bit of a — cult's not the right word — but certainly a fellowship."

After learning the ropes of offshore racing, Philip Bell's first Sydney to Hobart aboard She was in 2016. (Supplied: Richard Bennett Photography)

Bell's first Sydney to Hobart was in 2016. He built up his experience starting with local races on the Gold Coast, then more than a handful of races in North Queensland and the Whitsundays and northern NSW leading into 2016.

So what is life like sailing beyond the margins?

"Because we live such a comfortable life on land every now and then to be out on the edge actually gives you an incentive to, and it makes you, appreciate your comfortable bed at home and the nice things that we've got around us," Bell says.

"It's a reminder that being on the edge and not being necessarily totally in control of everything [that] nature's probably in control."

The skipper says there are a lot of fanatical people who love the race who take part over and over again, pointing to the instructor for his sea safety certificate who had taken part in 47 Sydney to Hobarts.

Philip Bell's first Sydney to Hobart with She in 2016 ended with an eighth-placed finish in her PHS division. (Supplied: Philip Bell)

"He's a great instructor because we've all faced serious issues at sea," Bell says.

"If you stay at sea long enough you'll experience the whole raft of experiences from beautiful sailing to being becalmed to being in a storm.

"And a lot of people say that racing is like 80 per cent boredom, 10 per cent joy and 10 per cent terror."

In 2023 She failed to make the finish due to the mainsail blowing out.

"We sailed for another half a day. And then when we looked at the forecast and we said 'this is not so smart'," Bell says.

"Safety being the key, you've got eight people to worry about, we decided to turn around."

Skipper Philip Bell had to pull She out of the race in 2023, receiving the inauspicious trophy for the first boat into Eden. (Supplied: Philip Bell)

Bell is quite clear about his number one concern during the race.

"Because we can't stop overnight at a motel we've got to continue the race until we get to the end. So therefore one of the biggest factors, especially in the 40-footers, is fatigue," he says.

After the first few hours charging south down the coast with spinnaker up, the crew shift into "four up, four down" mode, with half on shift at any one time to allow them to have "something left in the tank on day three".

"I've got a stations list of what everyone has to do because not everyone's got exactly the same skills. So I have to know what each person is capable of and make the most of that," he says.

Philip Bell (second left, front row) and the full crew of eight on board She before the 2022 Sydney to Hobart. (Supplied: Philip Bell/Crew partner)

If there's one thing Bell sees as a barrier for sailors to completing the Hobart, it's a fairly obvious one.

"I don't get seasick. I don't think you could do this job if you got seasick," he says.

"I mean, I did have a 2IC in the 2017 Hobart who did get seasick, but somehow he coped.

"I dunno how he did it, but he coped and he'd get up every shift. He'd get up and spew his guts out and do what he had to do and he'd go back to sleep — the next shift the same."

Bell has seen plenty of different conditions in his time doing the Hobart — this year will be his sixth.

"The only surprise was in 2019 when the fires were on, those fires just created a massive micro-climate," he says.

"For example, we got becalmed off St Helen's and then we picked up wind and we got to Tasman Island.

"Then when we turned into Storm Bay, instead of it being freezing, that wind was so hot [and] blowing at about 35 knots (64.8km/h) that the stanchions, the stainless steel stanchions, people leaned up against them and they got burned.

"It was like 40 degrees and driven by the fires around Eden, across Bass Strait, and the northerly was just amazing."

The Sydney to Hobart went ahead in 2019 but fires created their own micro-climate for racers. (Getty Images: Alea/Andrea Francolini)

What does Bell hope to get from this year's race?

"I'm 73, 74 next year and I know that I can't keep doing this for that much longer," he says.

"Whether this will be the last or the second to last, I don't know.

"But then if you stop then you're not going back, are you?"

There is another driving force behind this year's race.

"Peter Rodgers, who was a good friend of mine, the previous owner, a real character in Sydney, he passed away in December last year," Bell says.

"And we promised [Rodger's wife] Pat that we would make some gesture with that. So we're having Peter Rodgers Memorial Race on our jerseys this year."

The Peter Rodgers Memorial Race

As the crew is gathered in Sydney to prepare for the race, Rodgers will be on most of their minds.

Skipper Peter Rodgers (left) and second-in-command Mark O'Dea shared many Sydney to Hobarts together. (Supplied: Mark O'Dea)

O'Dea was the 2IC for the former owner over many races and has been involved with the boat on and off for many years.

He says Rodgers, who died aged 86, was a personality but not a hands-on skipper.

"He tended to keep out of things a lot, decisions like what direction to go and what sails to put up. But he really, really enjoyed it [sailing and the race]," O'Dea says.

"He put a lot of money into the boat and a lot of time, he was very dedicated.

"I think it was his escape. He was running a business, a big accountancy firm in the city, and I think that managerial task and all that responsibility, I think he needed some sort of escape from that, and sailing was it."

One story O'Dea remembers fondly involves the Iron Pot Lighthouse, a red and white landmark for sailors on the edge of the Derwent River that marks the start of the final section of the race.

For former She skipper Peter Rodgers, the Iron Pot Lighthouse was not just a landmark but a source of frustration. (Getty Images: Andrea Francolini)

"Every single time we went past this — and he [Rodgers] would say 'if I'm asleep when we get to the Iron Pot, wake me up' — he'd yell and scream at it," O'Dea says.

"He was an eccentric fella, and quite funny — he used to swear at this damn thing really loud, thank God there weren't any houses around.

"He'd say 'you've cost me thousands and thousands of dollars, you bloody thing, you make me come down here every year'.

"He'd have us all in stitches on the deck, but that is what that race is all about — memories of things like that. And then [after the outburst] he'd just go downstairs and have a sleep. Iron Pot abuse."

Whereas Bell came to sailing late, O'Dea has been doing it nearly all his life.

His career involves the water too as he is a shipwright, or boat builder.

"I was lucky enough to be born near Middle Harbour [in Sydney] and that's what we did in the school holidays was boats, boats, boats," he says.

"It taught us all at an early age how to read the breeze and read the currents."

Mark O'Dea helped build a number of America's Cup boats for Australian sailing great Syd Fischer (left). (Getty Images: Stephen Dunn)

O'Dea was a determined sailor, with lofty dreams. He remembers listening to broadcasts of the America's Cup on a crystal radio set in his room in the '60s.

He went on to help build five America's Cup boats, most with the great Syd Fischer, and was on the extended sailing list for Steak N'Kidney in the 1987 challenger series.

His first Sydney to Hobart was in 1984, one of the worst years in the race's history.

Asked why people race in these big races over and over, he replies:

"Probably because you forget about all the bad things [about the race]. You've got 12 months to forget about it," O'Dea says.

"When I did my '84 race it took me four years to go back and do another one. The '84 race was a particularly hard race and it was the first time we actually lost someone in the race.

"We made it [home safely] but it was really, really tough."

This year, She will make her 23rd race trip to Hobart, placing it seventh in the all-time list behind Bacardi, which this year will race for the 32nd time.

"[She is] 43 foot long and it's 43 years old. It's older than my car, and I think that's old," O'Dea says.

"People say 'wow, the car's still running', but I tinker with it … and I work on it.

"I'm proud of the old car and I'm proud of this old yacht.

"And it's been very successful over the years, three times it's won overall PHS, division one and division two — 2009, 2012 and 2013.

"We rely on heavy weather and attrition compared to the lighter boats that don't last there that long when it's really, really rough.

"We cane it pretty hard out there … we push it to the max."

Forty three years on, She is still racing with the best of them in Queensland and in the Sydney to Hobart. (Supplied: Airlie Beach Race Week Committee)

Asked what's bringing him back to this boat once again, O'Dea cites the memorial for Rodgers, but says there's much more that grabs him for this world-famous race.

"That is part of it [remembering Peter], but the rest of it is me just enjoying that boat, the way it sails. I can trust it," O'Dea says.

"I could be on a lighter boat, and if conditions are right you could outpace everybody.

"I could possibly get on a maxi boat if I really wanted to, but I prefer to be on a smaller boat with eight people that I can relate to.

"And we all learn off each other."

The 80th edition of the Sydney to Hobart yacht race will begin on Boxing Day at 1pm AEDT. You can follow day one of the race in ABC's live blog from midday AEDT.

title: 'Aussie' poster in Adelaide vandalised with 'white power' graffiti
text:
An Adelaide street artist's poster aimed at provoking thought about national identity has been vandalised with racist graffiti.

The artwork, which depicts late 19th century Muslim immigrant Monga Khan above the headline "Aussie", was found defaced on Wednesday morning with a spray-painted "white power" message.

The poster was displayed on the corner of Hackney Road and North Terrace on the outskirts of the Adelaide CBD.

An "Aussie" artwork poster by Peter Drew vandalised with "white power". (ABC News: Lincoln Rothall)

Artist Peter Drew, who began displaying his "Aussie" artwork series around Adelaide and other capital cities in 2016, estimated that he replaces a poster "once a month" due to racist vandalism.

He hit back at the perpetrator on Wednesday.

"They call themselves 'patriots' but they are not patriotic," he said.

"They don't love Australia. They love a fantasy of an Australia that never really was.

"We are the real patriots. We love Australia for what it actually is and what it might yet become."

Drew replaced the vandalised artwork on Wednesday afternoon with a new poster, which depicts protesters at a March for Australia rally tearing down a Monga Khan poster.

The vandalised poster has been replaced with a new artwork. (Supplied: Peter Drew)

This poster has the headline "Aussie?".

He added that "as a rule", he puts up three new posters for every one that is vandalised.

'Not just any old thing that's been graffitied'

Dr Kaz Ross, independent researcher into far-right extremism in Australia, said public commentary like the slogan pictured "has a very corrosive effect — and that's the intention of it".

"The intention is to indicate to the target audience, 'You're not welcome here, this is our space,'" she said.

"If you're not the target audience, you may not even feel it particularly deeply.

"But if you are the target audience, you know that there's someone basically expressing hate towards you … and the intention is to make you feel very, very uncomfortable on the streets in Australia."

The vandalised artwork depicts late 19th century Muslim immigrant Monga Khan. (ABC News: Lincoln Rothall)

Dr Ross said it was significant that the vandal had targeted one of Drew's posters, which feature people who applied for exemptions to the White Australia policy.

She said the images drew attention to the fact that "White Australia was never just white Australia".

"It's not just any old thing that's been graffitied here. It's quite a symbolic statement about who's an Australian and who's welcome in Australia," she said.

What Is A Real Aussie? Street artist Peter Drew beings a new project asking What Is A Real Aussie?

"So it's important that we say 'Yes, actually these people on the posters contributed to the making of modern Australia and they are welcome as Australians.'"

Drew said graffiti also forced him recently to replace an "Aussie" poster that depicted a Jewish World War II veteran.

Shai Wittles, a member of the Jewish community in Adelaide, said tensions had escalated following the Bondi attack.

"What I'm seeing is, in the wake of this tragedy, I'm seeing white supremacists emboldened and I'm seeing a lot of people using Bondi as a justification for their white supremacy," they said.

"I think that these escalations are making everyone less safe."

They said the intent behind incidents such as the graffiti was to stoke division within the community.

Minister says act doesn't represent SA

Minister for Multicultural Affairs Zoe Bettison said the message was "offensive and disappointing".

Zoe Bettison calls on South Australians to "stand together in the spirit of unity".

"While acts like this can be hurtful and divisive, they do not reflect who we are as a community," she said in a statement.

"South Australia is an overwhelmingly harmonious and inclusive multicultural state.

"It's important we all take time to reflect on the recent events and be reminded of the values of kindness, respect and looking out for one another.

"South Australians reject hate and continue to stand together in the spirit of unity and goodwill."

Monga Khan was a hawker and itinerant worker who arrived in Australia in 1895 shortly before the White Australia policy began.

He applied for an exemption to the policy's dictation test so he could be re-admitted into Australia without taking the test designed to keep him out.

The image depicted in the poster is from his application for the exemption.

title: Festive 'Friendsmas' celebrations combat loneliness, social isolation
text:
Our screens are brimming with commercials of happy families celebrating Christmas, but for some Australians the festive season is actually the loneliest time of year.

Mission Australia has been fielding phone calls every single day in the lead-up to Christmas, from people who have nowhere to spend it.

The demand aligns with data showing the frequency of social contact, both in-person and online, has been declining in Australia for the past two decades.

Analysis from the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare found loneliness and social isolation were exacerbated since the COVID-19 pandemic.

"Social isolation and loneliness are among the many factors that can be detrimental to a person's wellbeing," it reported.

Celebrating with mates

Darwin is Australia's smallest capital city, with some of the country's most expensive airline fees, so it's not uncommon to be separated from loved ones in December.

For people in remote Australia who can't be with family these holidays, celebrating with your chosen family for a "Friendsmas" helps foster a sense of connection.

These Top End mates celebrated Friendsmas at Tiwi, in Darwin's northern suburbs. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)

For 26-year-old Dana McDonald, visits to family interstate can be few and far between, so she cherishes her Friendsmas celebrations in Darwin.

"You get to spend deliberate time with the people that you love deeply," she says.

" It definitely helps with a lot of the loneliness you feel at this time of year, living away from family and feeling maybe disconnected. "

Dana says spending quality, intentional time with loved ones fosters a sense of social connection — the delicious Christmas ham is just an added bonus. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)

Dana says "that's the beauty of" a transient place like Darwin: "You make friends for life".

"That's what I've recognised since being up here in the last few years, is that it's not the amount of time, it's the quality of time," she says.

Gifts aren't essential at Friendsmas, it all depends on how your mates decide to celebrate. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)

Dana says "it's not unusual to feel lonely this time of year", so, after a long, hot 2025, she believes the best way to celebrate the silly season is with "people that make you feel good, that fill your cup".

Shane Butcher, 36, and his wife are among those special people — they're keen to make Friendsmas an annual tradition.

Shane says Friendsmas is all about spending quality time with good company. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)

"We're all here together because life gets a bit too busy and we can't catch up all the time, so it's just good to set aside a day, exchange a few presents, have a good Christmas lunch and just enjoy," he says.

Their celebration changes each festive season, from building gingerbread houses to playing video games and enjoying a movie, but the one constant every year is sharing "those belly laughs".

Shane says Darwin always has "perfect weather, unless it's raining, and even then it's still pretty good", so a dip in the pool is usually on the Friendsmas agenda. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)

Sharing a meal

But geography isn't the only factor contributing to isolation in the holidays.

From Australia's smallest capital to its most populous, social connection remains just as vital.

Christmas puts meaningful connections in the spotlight, but not everyone has family to celebrate with. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)

In Sydney's Marrickville, people gather weekly to share a meal at Addison Road Community Organisation.

The charity's chief executive, Rosanna Barbero, says attendees from all walks of life connect at their services.

She says December is the most important time of year for these events.

Addison Road Community Organisation combats loneliness and food insecurity with regular meal services in Sydney. (ABC News: Zac Pitkethley)

"If you switch on the television, you're always being reminded that it's the festive, joyful period," she says.

"There's commercials about buying food and cooking for Christmas Day, and being surrounded by happy, smiling families that are singing carols.

" There are so many people that are not in that situation, so it's a constant reminder that you are alone. "

In addition to social events, the charity also runs a community pantry that opens each afternoon.

Rosanna Barbero says many community members attend the services to connect with others and share a meal. (ABC News: Mridula Amin)

Rosanna says locals will gather outside in the hours before the pantry opens, to catch up with each other and those working behind the scenes.

Barry Shuttleworth is part of the 800-strong army of volunteers and has been spreading the silly season joy dressed up in his daughter's "Moo-ry Cow-ristmas" costume.

For anyone battling loneliness today, he suggests seeking out the "great feeling of joy and support" that fills the air around these community events.

Barry Shuttleworth is spreading joy this silly season. (Facebook: Addi Road Community Organisation)

Connecting with community

Over in Perth, Carley Smith has been working with more than 350 volunteers to deliver Mission Australia's 50th annual Christmas Lunch in the Park (CLIP).

She says it's an open invitation, with 1,650 three-course meals prepared ahead of the big day, and no guest is ever turned away.

For guests aged 14 and over, Mission Australia care packages will offer toiletries and non-perishable food items. (ABC News: Rick Rifici)

It's the biggest event of its kind in the country and Carley loves the rewarding sense of celebration and joy it delivers at a time when "cost of living is obviously impacting everybody".

Mission Australia has seen an uptick in the volume of people reaching out for support, and she says events like CLIP help families who can't afford lots of presents or a big Christmas Day lunch.

Santa will be present at the community-funded event, with lots of children's presents ready to go. (ABC News: Rick Rifici)

The support sometimes comes full circle — Carley says a number of former guests now serve others at the event.

"One of the volunteers, her only positive memories of Christmas Day as a child, was when she attended CLIP," she says.

"That story just breaks my heart but it shows what a difference Christmas Lunch in the Park can make to a family."

Carley says it's important to be kind to ourselves and others because "sometimes, that Christmas period is a really tough time of year".

Mission Australia's Carley Smith says it can be tough to maintain relationships with loved ones living far away, but sometimes a quick phone call is all it takes to spark a sense of connection. (ABC News: Rick Rifici)

If there's someone in your life struggling with loneliness, she suggests heeding the advice of a famous proverb: "When you have more than you need, build a longer table, not a higher fence".

"If you've got space for extras on Christmas Day, reach out to your friends that might be isolated, that might not have family close by, invite them over — you'll have a fun time," Carley says.

"If you are far from your family and friends, it's really tough to keep those relationships going but it's lovely to reach out."

title: How second-hand shopping could be fuelling consumption
text:
Second-hand shopping has long been promoted as part of the solution to Australia's waste problem, with many consumers choosing pre-loved items as a more sustainable alternative to traditional retail.

As consumers embrace thrifting and circular fashion, Australia's second-hand market is now predicted to reach about $1.5 billion by 2032, according to market research platform Credence Research.

Seamless says 222,000 tons of clothing ended up in Australian landfill last year. (ABC News: Paul Robinson)

But despite this growth, the volume of clothing thrown to waste remains high. According to the clothing stewardship scheme Seamless Australia, more than 220,000 tonnes of clothing were sent to landfill in 2024, a decrease of 1 per cent from the previous year.

It has left some shoppers and sellers questioning whether the thrifting industry is successfully helping Australians reduce consumption.

Second-hand jewellery is popular at market stores. (ABC News: Mae Argent)

Spending less does not always mean consuming less

Research released by the Australia Institute in 2024 found Australians buy more clothes per person than any other country, with an average of 56 items.

Associate professor in fashion at Queensland University of Technology, Tiziana Ferrero-Regis, said circularity — giving clothing a longer lifetime — is essential to helping reduce the production of textile waste.

But she said shoppers can fall into a problematic mindset when buying pre-loved clothing.

"Moral licensing, in a very short summary, is 'I buy second-hand clothing so I can buy more,'" she said.

Tiziana Ferrero-Regis says second-hand shopping does not necessarily reduce consumption. (Supplied)

Dr Ferrero-Regis said for many shoppers, fashion resale apps do not necessarily slow consumption behaviour and the speed of purchases.

"Consumers of second-hand clothing now behave in the same way they buy fast fashion," she said.

Cost-conscious family embraces the spirit of 'Thriftmas' Rising expenses across the festive season have driven a family of five in Brisbane to set a rule to only purchase Christmas presents from second-hand stores — and they've been pleasantly surprised by the treasures they've uncovered.

"Second-hand clothing has the potential to reduce consumption, but it's not a given, it's not automatic.

"The problem is that online and social media resales can become addictive in the same ways as fast fashion.

"We see the same kind of behaviour [including] compulsive buying."

Apps driving growth in resale market

The rapid growth of online resale platforms like eBay and Depop is a key driver of the market's expansion, according to Credence Research.

A Depop spokesperson said sign-ups in Australia have grown "over 100 per cent year-on-year" as more consumers look for second-hand items.

"Resale is becoming a mainstream way to shop," the spokesperson said.

Esta Padillo sells second-hand clothes on Depop. (Supplied)

Esta Padillo, who had been selling clothing on the platform for almost a decade, said the second-hand buying and selling experience had changed significantly over the years.

She said ultra-fast fashion drop-shippers had increasingly bought from sites like Shein and Temu, then resold the items at inflated "vintage" prices.

"Back in the day that didn't really happen, so I think that's the main change that's breaking my heart," Ms Padillo said.

"This is not what Depop is supposed to be at all."

A clothing rack at a second-hand market. (ABC News: Mae Argent)

According to Depop policy, drop-shipped catalogue items are not allowed on the app, and submitting misleading or untrue listings on Depop is against their Terms of Service.

When asked about the sale of fast-fashion items on the app, a Depop spokesperson said the platform did not discriminate based on the type of items sold.

"Every second-hand purchase helps shift behaviour in ways that support a circular economy and reduce the environmental impact of new fashion," the spokesperson said.

"It is important to us that we showcase an alternative to new fast fashion that's kinder to people and the planet than buying new … we've taken steps to ban less sustainable sourcing practices."

Some people buy clothes from sites like Shein and Temu, then resell the items at inflated "vintage" prices. (ABC News: Mae Argent)

Fast fashion brands surge on resale platforms

Fast fashion brands were increasingly turning up in physical second-hand stores, markets and op-shops.

Isobel Dear founded a second-hand market in 2020 after noticing a lack of pre-loved fashion events, and said digital media had played a critical role in encouraging more people to embrace second-hand shopping.

"Social media and digital platforms have made circular fashion more accessible," she said.

Isobel Dear founded a second-hand market in 2020. (ABC News: Mae Argent)

"I think that digitally just being able to spread the word through those platforms has definitely helped us form this niche community."

Ms Dear said she does not encourage "those ultra-fast fashion brands that are really low quality" being sold at her market, but sellers often donate items they have been unable to sell.

She said the store receives about five bins of donations each week, many of them fast-fashion items.

Isobel Dear says digital media plays a critical role in encouraging more people to embrace second-hand shopping. (ABC News: Mae Argent)

Ms Dear said she was trying to support the shopping style and community the market had created, while also encouraging shoppers to avoid fast-fashion items and choose longer-lasting pieces.

"If we can keep those [good quality] pieces in rotation then hopefully those really low-quality items just eventually are not the preference," she said.

"We can still love fashion for what it does for our personalities, and our style, and the joy that we get from it … if we can just be a little more mindful with it."

title: What you need to know before you buy lab-grown versus natural diamonds
text:
The slogan of "a diamond is forever" — linking diamonds to everlasting love and ultimate commitment — has been instilled for decades.

Diamonds are generally considered a luxury asset that holds its value, but the emergence of laboratory-grown diamonds in the jewellery industry over recent years could challenge that belief.

Are synthetic diamonds real diamonds, and what do you need to know before making a purchase?

Let's break it down.

Are laboratory-grown diamonds actually diamonds?

Yes, lab-grown diamonds, also known as synthetic diamonds or man-made diamonds, have identical chemical, physical and optical properties to their natural counterparts.

Despite their near-identical appearance, trained gemologists and sophisticated equipment can still detect subtle differences.

Uncut natural diamonds in different colours. (Supplied: Geoscience Australia)

Natural diamonds, or mined diamonds, are extremely rare compared to other minerals, according to Geoscience Australia.

They form at depths of 150 to 200 kilometres below the Earth's surface where high temperatures and pressures allow them to crystallise.

Then the diamonds may be picked up by hot magma and transported upwards as the magma intrudes into the Earth's crust.

Natural diamond rings and diamonds on a display tray with a 10-carat ring (left) worth $698,000. (ABC News: Yiying Li)

Most natural diamonds are between 1 and 3 billion years old.

According to Macquarie University, the two main methods for growing synthetic diamonds today are the high-pressure, high-temperature (HPHT) method and chemical vapour deposition (CVD).

HPHT mimics Earth's conditions to create diamonds, while CVD grows them atom-by-atom in a vacuum chamber by exposing a diamond seed to carbon-rich gases.

De Beers employees work on belt presses for HPHT-synthesised diamonds in a laboratory. (Getty Images: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg)

How do lab-grown diamonds compare to natural ones financially?

From a quality perspective, synthetic diamonds benefit from highly controlled production environments, resulting in a consistently strong cut, colour and clarity, the Jewellers Association of Australia (JAA) has told the ABC.

"Yet one of their most significant drawbacks is their negligible resale value," a spokesperson from the JAA said.

"In circumstances where jewellery is later sold, such as after the breakdown of a marriage, the intrinsic worth of a synthetic diamond is effectively zero, leaving only the value of the precious metal.

"On the other hand, because synthetic diamonds are substantially cheaper than natural stones, the overall financial loss to consumers can be lower."

The spokesperson noted that many buyers preferred natural diamonds for their geological rarity and the long-standing heritage of mined gemstones.

A bench jeweller crafts a natural diamond earring in a workshop. (ABC News: Yiying Li)

In general, lab-grown diamonds are 30-70 per cent cheaper than natural ones per carat.

The price of lab-grown diamonds was expected to drop further as production capacity increases, the JAA said.

Therefore, synthetic diamonds should not be considered investment stones and must be marketed accordingly, and retailers' clear disclosure remains paramount, the association said.

Do lab-grown diamonds have a future in Australia?

Experts say yes, with younger consumers being the main driving force.

Millennials and gen Z would drive virtually all luxury market growth going forward, said Marty Hurwitz, a co-founder of the Global Diamond Trade Organisation (GDTO).

Marty Hurwitz says the market for lab-grown diamonds could reach as much as 70 per cent by the end of 2026. (Supplied)

"These buyers prize sustainability, transparency, and digital fluency — values that are already reshaping every corner of discretionary spending," Mr Hurwitz said.

"Our research estimates show the current retail market share between 50-60 per cent in favour of lab-grown diamonds in Australia."

He said it could reach as much as 70 per cent by the end of 2026.

Synthetic diamonds were also increasingly used in watchmaking and other design applications, the JAA noted.

The association added that sustainability and responsible sourcing were also influencing purchasing decisions in younger Australians.

A miner shows an estimated 5 to 7-carat diamond found near an Angolan village. (Getty Images: Olivier Polet/Corbis)

However, the JAA said it was important to recognise that natural diamond mining supported local employment and communities in several developing nations.

Historically, so-called "blood diamonds" or "conflict diamonds" had been used to help fund armed conflicts, particularly in Africa.

Over the past couple of decades however there has been a concerted international effort to reduce trade in stones of dubious origin.

What do jewellers think?

Justin Linney, the creative director of Linneys, a natural diamond jeweller, has criticised some lab-grown diamond retailers for leveraging "market confusion" and providing "misleading information".

"The growth in synthetic diamond factories has been driven largely by the misleading marketing term 'lab-grown diamonds', when in reality these are synthetic by definition," he said.

It should be a considered choice to buy natural or lab-grown diamond jewellery. (ABC News: Yiying Li)

"For some consumers who thought they were purchasing a more environmentally friendly option they are now shocked to see the factory and conditions where these stones are produced.

" And for consumers who purchased synthetic diamonds over the last few years as a cost-effective alternative, these stones have since lost considerable value. "

While defending natural diamonds, Mr Linney has acknowledged the impact of lab-grown diamonds, saying his business has certainly seen a drop in sales of $4,000-8,000 diamond rings, where buyers in that market might be opting for synthetics.

Different lab-grown diamond rings ranged from one to three carats on display. (ABC News: Yiying Li)

Myrtle Polymenopoulos, the retail operations manager for Austen & Blake in Australia and New Zealand, which sells both natural and lab-grown diamonds, said lab-grown diamonds were not replacing natural diamonds but expanding the market instead.

"Lab-grown diamonds are reshaping the world of jewellery," Ms Polymenopoulos said.

"They have made larger stones, distinctive settings or bespoke creations accessible without stretching a customer's spend.

" It should be a considered choice with consumers fully aware of the facts and, importantly, the origin of their diamond. "

She added that it would come down to the customer's perspective and priorities when deciding which kind of diamond to buy.

title: This couple is on opposite sides of the political divide. Here's how they make it work
text:
When Erin Rolandsen signed up for online dating, she set a filter to only search for men who identify as left-wing.

It wasn't long before her future husband popped up in her messages.

They were deep into dating before she realised he hadn't nominated his political preferences on his profile.

And some of his views were, in fact, quite different to her own.

"We'd had discussions about current affairs, and I always thought he had very good opinions," she said.

" But it wasn't until significantly later that I realised he actually really loved political leaders that I despised. "

Erin Rolandsen met her husband through online dating. (Supplied: Erin Rolandsen)

Reeling from this revelation but "in too deep", Erin had an epiphany one day during her commute — to work through their differences, she imagined the two of them riding on a bus together.

"He's looking out the right side and telling me what he sees, and I'm looking out the left side and telling him what I see," she said.

"Understanding both perspectives helps us understand our landscape better.

"What matters is that we remind ourselves that we are on the same bus and headed in the same direction."

Politics impacting more relationships

Political differences are increasingly impacting our relationships, according to the latest national data.

Relationships Australia says the number of couples struggling because of differing values and beliefs — including political views — has almost doubled in just two years.

More Australian relationships are being impacted by political differences. (Unsplash: Priscilla Du Preez)

Its 2024 national survey revealed roughly a quarter of Australians said this was a major stress for their relationship — and experts say anecdotally, it is only getting worse.

The service's national executive officer Nick Tebbey says people are becoming increasingly resolute and "in tune" with their beliefs, and this is causing more conflict.

"The online community has given us permission to quickly block a person or unfollow a person if we don't like what they're saying," he said.

" But you can't suddenly stop talking to your partner of 10 years. "

'That creates a splinter'

Ben has dated several women on the other side of the political divide.

The 21-year-old, who has asked to change his name for anonymity, describes himself as "centre-right".

He said while political differences can be challenging, they are also a blessing.

"But both people must be open minded to each other's points of view," he said.

"Most of the time you both want the same outcome and just disagree on the process to get there."

More Australian couples say they are struggling because of different values and beliefs. (Unsplash: Pat Ferranco)

Ben believes biased mainstream media outlets are contributing to increasing strain between couples — but he said online algorithms were the biggest culprit.

"You only see far right and far left content. And if that's all you see, then that's what most people who don't do their due diligence will just believe," he said.

" That creates a splinter in the relationship. "

Online algorithms a major driver

Mr Tebbey agreed online algorithms were a major driver of this shift, creating an echo chamber that feeds consumers more of the same content.

"That leads to an inability to see something from a different perspective, because I've had so much confirmation that my perspective is the right perspective," he said.

Nick Tebbey says more Australian couples are struggling with political differences. (Supplied.)

A growing number of Australians are also opting to get their news — often heavily biased commentary or disinformation — from social media.

"They're accepting what they're reading online, as true as fact, without necessarily understanding that there could be a whole lot of different opinion and sometimes ulterior motives behind it," he said.

Mr Tebbey said some couples were now refusing to discuss politics entirely because of their differences.

Others are continuing to talk about it, but swiftly spiralling into arguments or miscommunication.

These clashes can have a "domino effect", Mr Tebbey said, triggering fears about other issues such as roles in the household or how to raise children.

'This doesn't have to be the end'

Mr Tebbey said in some cases, breaking up may be the best option — but it's not always the first response.

"This doesn't have to be the end of a relationship," he said.

Young men flocked right in the US election. Will it happen here? Young men across the world have been embracing right-wing politics, while young women have moved to the left. Will it happen in the Australian election too?

He advised couples to set ground rules around future political discussions to ensure they are open and respectful.

"For instance — we will hear each other out and try to see things from the other's perspective without immediately minimising or ridiculing the other person for the beliefs they have," Mr Tebbey said.

"That isn't easy, because we get built up in our own beliefs that we're right and everyone else must therefore be wrong."

He also recommended couples seek support and counselling.

"This is an issue that's affecting a lot of people," he said.

"You're not alone."
